column7: description

A man loses his family to the British and suffers as a POW during the Napoleonic Wars. Years after the end of the war he finds his British captor in need of help. Instead of vengence he chooses forgiveness and rescues the British captain and his family.  The film was shot in the many islands of Stockholm Archipelago; in the film, the island is described only as "uttermost and barren."
L'Homme du large explores themes of forgiveness and repentance in a melodrama about a Breton fisherman.
L'Homme du large explores themes of forgiveness and repentance in a melodrama about a Breton fisherman.

This documentary (although largely staged) follows an Inuk family (Nanook and his family) live and perform daily tasks during a winter in the Ungava Peninsula of Quebec, Canada. The film portrays them as relentless heroes, their lifestyle exotic, and their environment unforgiving.

Cœur Fidéle is a melodrama about Marie and her tragic romance, set against the docks of Marseilles. The film features iconic techniques of photogénie, many of which involve images of water combined with the cross-dissolve.

The titular canal flows from the city of Auxerre, in the Burgundy region southeast to Paris, to Decize, a city in Central France, connectig the Yonne river and the Loire river. The Canal du Nivernais is Epstein made La Belle Nivernaise in 1923, the same year he filmed Cœur fidéle. The film is an adaptation of a short story written by Alphonse Daudet and tells the story of an orphan boy growing up by the river.

The titular canal flows from the city of Auxerre, in the Burgundy region southeast to Paris, to Decize, a city in Central France, connectig the Yonne river and the Loire river. The Canal du Nivernais is Epstein made La Belle Nivernaise in 1923, the same year he filmed Cœur fidéle. The film is an adaptation of a short story written by Alphonse Daudet and tells the story of an orphan boy growing up by the river.

An adaptation of the 1917 novel of the same title, Kœnigsmark is a story about a schoolteacher who discovers a crime. The filmmaker insisted on creating a faithful adaptation to the original novel and therefore filming in Germany: the film was, at least partially, shot near the Neuschwanstein Castle (which can be seen in the film).

Photographer Herbert Ponting accompanied British explorer Captain Falcon Scott to the British Antartic Expedition (1910-1913, also called the Terra Nova expedition) to the South Pole. After showing the expedition crew sailing into the Southern Ocean and preparing to move towards the South Pole, the film ends with a sequene of the crew leaving their base, followed by title cards that explain that Scott and the explorers never returned from the Pole.

Three women are in love with one man. An early work by Epstein, the film shows the usual techinques of camera movement and superimposition by the director. The film was shot in Paris and in the town of L'Isle-Adam by the river Oise.

column4: La Chute de la maison Usher
column7: Perhaps the best known film by Epstein, La Chute de la maison Usher tells the story of Usher through his friend, an unknown narrator. The film is an adaptation of two short stories by Poe.  The film was shot in three different locations: the interior in Studios Éclair and Menchen in Épinay-sur-Seine near Paris; the exteriors in Sologne (with the river Sologne) and Vexin (a historical region in northern France).

column4: La Chute de la maison Usher
column7: Perhaps the best known film by Epstein, La Chute de la maison Usher tells the story of Usher through his friend, an unknown narrator. The film is an adaptation of two short stories by Poe.  The film was shot in three different locations: the interior in Studios Éclair and Menchen in Épinay-sur-Seine near Paris; the exteriors in Sologne (with the river Sologne) and Vexin (a historical region in northern France).

Maldone is a story about a man who runs away from his estate, becomes a canal worker, and finds love, only to be called back home and marry a different woman. The film notes the waterway as the Briare Canal and its Saint-Jean lock (which does not exist; most similar is Saint Joseph lock).

This experimental documentary short is a montage of close-ups of the then-newly built Koningshaven Bridge (Koninginnebrug / "De Hef") in Rotterdam and the trains and ships that pass by it, in the backdrop of which is seen the port of Rotterdam.

Buster Keaton plays Bill Canfield Jr., or Steamboat Jr.: an awkward and eccentric son of Bill Canfield who owns a paddle steamer and is slowly losing business to a newer steamer. The film follows Bill Jr.'s visit home that is filled with mishaps but eventually helps his father and his business. The film is set to be in River Junction, MS, while Bill Jr., is based in Boston. The film production took place on a set in Sacramento; John Bengtson of silentlocations.com, crediting historian Paul Frobose, provides some shot-by-shot comparisons between map coordinates and the landmarks identified in the film (https://silentlocations.com/2011/04/18/buster-keaton-steamboat-bill-jr-locations/). Also see Jennifer Fay's discussion of the production process in The Inhospitable Planet.
A close-up look at sea urchins.
Finis Terrae marks the beginning of Epstein's repeated visits to Brittany. The film tells the simple story of two young kelp farmers on the islet of Bannec, near Ouessant.
Finis Terrae marks the beginning of Epstein's repeated visits to Brittany. The film tells the simple story of two young kelp farmers on the islet of Bannec, near Ouessant.

Regan is an experimental documentary that shows the city of Amsterdam before, during, and after a rainfall. The premiere of the film was held in De Ulitkijk, the theater of the Amsterdam Filmliga (now a hotel).
H2O is a cine-poem that shows water in its many different forms, made by photographer Ralph Steiner.
column15: National Film Registry (Library of Congress), https://www.loc.gov/item/2023600533/

column7: Subtitled "La Mer des corbeaux" (sea of crows), Mor'Vran is part documentary, part fiction film that portrays the many faces of life on the islands of Sein and Brest by loosely following a sailor (and his misfortunes).
Made a couple of years after H2O, Surf and Seaweed focuses on ocean tides swirling and surging, carrying seaweed and leaving marks on the soft sand.
A short documentary about the swimmer Jean Taris, featuring Vigo's novel techniques that highlight the swimmer's moving body. It was filmed mostly at the Automobile Club of France in Paris.
L'or des mer tells the story of an old Breton fisherman who finds a box of treasure from a washed up shipwreck.
Epstein experimented with metaphors and sound in this short film featuring Sully Prudhomme's poem set to the music of Gabriel Faure

Renoir's 1932 social satire film: Boudu, saved from drowning in River Seine by a middle class family and is given a second chance at a new life, challenges the newly learned manners and transgresses all rules. The film starts as Boudu takes a suicidal jump into the Seine from Pont des Arts.
A young woman is a travelling performer with a water-juggling act. She falls in love with a carriage driver. The film is still occasionally shown with a live benshi narration.

column4: Japanese Girls at the Harbor 港の日本娘, Minato no nihon musume
column7: Two schoolgirls drift apart when one of them falls for a boy with a motorcycle.
